name: solobuttons
text: And so Todd is forgotten

name: pyromancer
text: Picture of.

name: jthompson
text: YOU DOUBT ME? YOU FRIKKEN' DOUBT ME?

name: wae
text:
It's like a coke-head sunrise. The first light of morning comes through the blinds, you see a jogger or two outside, and it dawns on you like a damned freight-train that you desperately want to be anywhere but there, with ANYONE but the people you've just spent the last seven hours with in machine-gun conversation. The corner store still isn't open, so the cigarettes are gone. You're running low on warm busch lite.

And you have to walk home.
Fuck Todd.

name: ketamind
text:
I wish I could chubby this more, you have captured that moment perfectly.

Bravo.

name: joestork
text: I think recognize that.  Who are you quoting there?  Is it Lester Bangs?  I could be totally wrong...

name: kaithekender
text: As an ex-cokehead I can say you've described almost exactly what went through my head more mornings that I care to remember.

name: nelsonater
text: I'd pay to buy one of those books, even if it weren't for me.  Just the thought of famous people exacting some kind of attack on each other seems delightfully wonderful.

name: rogergs
text: Well, there is a lot of fanfic out there, but it's not exactly Bill vs. Steve, if you catch my drift.

name: drskradley
text:
Possible tasteless quotes from such slash fiction:
"Oh Steve, you are good at all kinds of Jobs..."
"And then, with furious enthusiasm, he lusciously entered his back Window..."

I disgust myself.

name: drskradley
text: Man, why did I bother writing that?  I wasn't even trying.

name: joestork
text: I thought it was funny.  Lusciously is a good adverb.

name: spectre
text: Microsoft's server products used to be known collectively as "Microsoft Back Office." The Cult of the Dead Cow's hacking tool for invading and manipulating Microsoft networks was known as "MS Back Oriface." I kid you not.

People like it cos he does it without being a dick, nor getting personal... and also because it often seems rather creative.

name: killerlimpet
text:
According to Erowid:

"Our understanding of the literature is that there is no such thing as safe use of most volatile solvents, aerosols or other street inhalants : their psychoactive effects may be inseparable from nerve and organ damage." (1)

Don't get high on brick cleaner, even if it makes your day. Even if Onstad endorses it via Todd.

Especially if Onstad endorses it via Todd.

(1) Erowid Inhalants Vault. http://erowid.org/chemicals/inhalants/inhalants.shtml
Accessed 10 Oct 2007

text:
Like some drug website run by people named Sun and Earth requires slavish adhesion to APA protocol.

Don't cry Erowid. You are rad. You are rad!

text: hey. HEY. in my part time hobby as a guy who occasionally vadalises wikipedia (and once also wrote a mildy humorous article about myself), i have learnt that referencing  is everything. or at least it is if you are trying to prove sonic has a boner in the title screen of the crystal caves zone in sonic 2.

text: ray has entrepreneurial ADD.

name: pyromancer
text: Later that week, Nate Jobs cons his way into the Delta Gamma Nu house to exact explosive revenge on "Moose" Gates.

name: mrcool1122
text: "Wink-nudge" margins are defined in the Chicago Manual of Style, under the chapter "Specious Padding Techniques."

name: hellofyellin
text: Man, spacious typography and wink-nudge margins were how I got through high school.  That and Courier New.  I guess that tactic would be under "Efficient Font Coverage".

name: twohundredninety
text: Man, I don't even know what would have happened if I'd ever turned a high school paper in in Courier New.

name: zefiel
text: What?

name: twohundredninety
text: Yeah, I dunno. We formatted papers in MLA, but every one of my teachers insisted that we use Times New Roman only, even though the format doesn't insist on it. They probably realized it could be used to make a paper look longer.

name: hellofyellin
text: Times New is for people with columns, baby.  Courier is easy to read, which is why its MLA-correct.  Plus it is, quite possibly the least sexy font (besides Comic Sans) and looks very small, so there is little to no sass-back from teachers who think you are trying to pad a paper.  Chubby for zefiel for reminding my why I am glad that I am done writing high-school papers.

name: stormagnet
text:
I've gotten around this before in OpenOffice by adding a custom paragraph style to pad out the individual character spacing, along with an unholy assortment of other whitespace cheats. The combined effect of a ton of tiny whitespace hacks is so hard to catch, yet I've padded a 5 page paper out to 7 with it.

(Styles and Formatting -> Default (Modify) -> Position -> Spacing -> Expanded for those who want to try this themselves. I also recommend tweaking your paragraph spacing setting. You can customize the line spacing too, so that "double-spaced" is closer to 2.5 spaced.)

Consider this my submission to the My God This Essay Topic Is Retarded Cookbook.

name: hellofyellin
text: My God, I wish I knew this in high school. I just started to use Open Office, and if I had figured out these tweaks, my life would have been so much easier.

name: alzuna
text: I used Corel Wordperfect and the way I got my paper to 5 or my pages was to ramble, a lot, but it was usually coherent with the topic, just a lot of tangents and commas. Unfortunately that habit has stuck with me today so my comments and forum posts are always a lot (A LOT) longer than they should be.

name: alzuna
text: *my = more

name: killingthejay
text: nothing nearly as bad as if you turned one in in comic sans.  the professor brings out the willow switch and an iron maiden whenever that happens.

name: killingthejay
text: and there is thunderous applause from the class, save for the dumbass who wrote a paper in comic sans and dared turn it in.

name: paperboy_2000
text: "Hey, Jobs! So, do you like Apples?" Gates shouted into the howling wind. "Well, how do you like them apples?!"

name: misterwolf
text: I love Ray's short attention span approach to capitalism. This is the second scheme in, like, what, six strips? But it is a good shift; making Todd a comedy star wasn't a very good idea, anyway.

Todd just loves brick cleaner.

name: woodenteeth
text: Panel 5 = Connies supreme, ultra-classy sass, the kind of guy who farts accidently and loudly, does not react, then looks over his shoulder a second later as if he's stepped on something hollow.

text: What about a story about Bill Gates gettin' high on brick cleaner and cussin' on the couch? Now THAT'S entertainment!

name: cailetshadow
text:
Gates: Move over, pre-wheelchair Stephen Hawking! You're hogging all the brick cleaner!

Hawking: I know when to stop, William! Just a little more. Just one more. What could possibly go wrong?

name: serf
text: Ah, I was wondering when the story arc copout was gonna happen.

name: thommy_h
text: I'm not sold on this story arc at all. Sorry.

name: augeno13
text: I'm just glad we're moving away from the Todd aspect of it.

name: sstralka
text:
The sudden shift here sort of reminds my of Monty Python's Flying Circus, the way they sometimes just suddenly lose interest in the sketch they're doing and don't even bother to wrap it up. They just move on to something else.

Which I always thought was admirably honest. It's hard enough to do a TV show every week, or a web comic (more or less) every (week) day without having to waste time finding an elegant way out of something that isn't working anymore.

name: wae
text: Coke-heads are funny, but they have a way of burning through all their material pretty quickly.

name: namdnas
text: Panel 3 is a t-shirt waiting to happen.

name: thatskotkid
text: CafePress is waiting.  Go, friend!  Follow your dream!

text: COPTIC, I TELL YOU!

name: boheeka
text: To be honest I think "We Can Do This!" would work better.

name: boheeka
text: How about a compromise (and yes I realize it's a month-plus after the fact): The art from panel three with "We Can Do This!".

text: I just realized Ray is speaking for Onstad in that final line of the penultimate panel.
